title: Charles Mingus - The Black Saint And The Sinner Lady [Impulse! I

Full covers included. No idea who is the original uploader. Thanks to him!

The Black Saint and the Sinner Lady is one of the greatest achievements in orchestration by any composer in jazz history. It veers between so many emotions that it defies easy encapsulation; for that matter, it can be difficult just to assimilate in the first place. Yet the work soon reveals itself as a masterpiece of rich, multi-layered texture and swirling tonal colors, manipulated with a painterÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s attention to detail. There are a few stylistic reference points ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ Ellington, the contemporary avant-garde, several flamenco guitar breaks ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ but the totality is quite unlike what came before it. Mingus relies heavily on the timbral contrasts between expressively vocal-like muted brass, a rumbling mass of low voices (including tuba and baritone sax), and achingly lyrical upper woodwinds, highlighted by altoist Charlie Mariano. Within that framework, Mingus plays shifting rhythms, moaning dissonances, and multiple lines off one another in the most complex, interlaced fashion heÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢d ever attempted. Mingus was sometimes pigeonholed as a firebrand, but the personal exorcism of Black Saint deserves the reputation ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ one neednÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t be able to follow the story line to hear the suffering, mourning, frustration, and caged fury pouring out of the music. The 11-piece group rehearsed the original score during a Village Vanguard engagement, where Mingus allowed the players to mold the music further; in the studio, however, his exacting perfectionism made The Black Saint and the Sinner Lady the first jazz album to rely on overdubbing technology.
